body.p:
Up to thee, show star of life, do we raise our eyes, when we
inquire after thy ways. Prepare

Clear then now our path, let
thy light shine unto us, and lead us according to thy pleasure,

Every thing has its time, and every endeavour under heaven has its
appointed hour! (Eccl. 3. I.) This sentence of the wise Shelomoh is universally
and indisputably applicable to all sublunary and temporal events; already
even will in the struggle for obtaining such (sub. & temp) possession will wisdom
and knowledge, even in the ordinary pursuits, in the occupations of civil
life will foresight and penetration of man particularly discover themselves,
if he in every undertaking does not suffer, the appointed time to pass by,
if he seizes the favourable moment for in all he does. And upon such
a just view of time, such an observation of the fit hour depends generally,
his attainment of or failure of in the object intended, his success or disap-
pointment in his undertakings.—Should there not also be such a proper
reason for the attainment of that, which is not alone necessary under heaven,
but which also reaches extends itself into the very heavens! yea
which stretches ever above them? Should there not be also found in our
heavenly calling, in our relations toward the supreme being such an
opportune hour, such a seasonable time, the proper use of which must
lead to a prosperous termination of this holy work, but the neglect of
which would render all our toil all our endeavours entirely useless?
Assuredly, my beloved brothers!__

We only need to look into sacred history, need only review the book of
the events of the world, to be clearly convinced, that all times were not
equally propitious towards spreading the knowledge and fear of God,
that divine tree of religion did not in every century produce its
nourishing fruit; we only need ask ourselves, to feel a lively and deep
conviction, that our time aera is not only the right but also the most
proper time for the revival and recuscitation of a religious life
in Yisrael; we only need look upon our gladdening commencement
to be assured, that we began at the proper time, at the appointed
hour, to gain true adorers to the divine word, devoted servants (minds) to
the service of the Lord But if in the temporal affairs of life it wisdom is not
considered wisdom to to consist only in having only made good use of the proper moment, to have
through which the matter desired was obtained; but also to devise means
to secure what we have acquired and to make the possession thereof permanent
should the greatest wisdom, which is proper to man, and which expresses
? the fear of God be less in this consideration? Should we rest
? having obtained a knowledge of religion without any

further effort to devise means, to acquire a situa state by which we
can keep ourselves in this wholesome and beneficial reverence toward an
alpowerful God? Are not religion and obedience to God and honouring
him, and the knowledge of his goodness from their very nature im-
perishable, as these gifts appertained to a life, which we deem eternal?

It is our duty, brethren, not only to teach the whole congregation,
but every individual of us the properties of the state, which I just
mentioned, that we may be the better enabled to reach it. Time
has shown that we have been successful in our holy endeavour, and
that we have chosen the proper hour, that we have acquired the
noblest of all possessions: it must be our aim to preserve it; you
must not expect that time can confirm you more and more in the
possession thereof; not expect that only from yourselves, from your
wisdom! With this view let us consider today:

Which state is the most propitious for the growth of religion
with whole nations and individuals? (single indiv.)
